title: 111_s3989
content: OFFSET OF RESTITUTION AND OTHER STATE JUDICIAL DEBTS AGAINST INCOME TAX REFUND. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow states to collect past-due judicial debts by designating a single entity to communicate debt information to the Secretary. The Internal Revenue Code allows states to collect past-due judicial debts by designating an entity to communicate debt information to the Secretary. The Secretary can reduce overpayments to individuals by the amount of the state judicial debt owed, pay the reduced amount to the state entity, and notify the individual of the collection. The Internal Revenue Code allows states to collect past-due judicial debts by reducing overpayments to individuals and notifying them of the reduction. The reduction is made to satisfy the state judicial debt, and the individual is informed of the offset. The Internal Revenue Code allows states to collect past-due debts by reducing overpayments to individuals for federal taxes, state income tax obligations, and debts owed to federal agencies. If the Secretary receives notice of multiple debts owed to a state agency or judicial branch, any overpayment by the individual will be used to satisfy the state debt. The Internal Revenue Code permits states to collect past-due debts by offsetting overpayments for federal taxes, state income taxes, and debts to federal agencies. If multiple debts are owed to a state agency or judicial branch, any overpayment will be applied towards those debts in the order they were accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply for notice and evidence consideration. A "past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt" refers to a debt resulting from a judgment or sentence in a court handling criminal or traffic cases in the State. The Internal Revenue Code allows states to collect past-due debts by offsetting overpayments for federal taxes, state income taxes, and debts to federal agencies. A "past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt" includes court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to crime victims resulting from a court judgment or sentence in criminal or traffic cases. The Secretary will issue regulations on how State designated entities must submit notices of past-due debts. The regulations will specify the types of State judicial debts eligible for reduction and the minimum debt amount. State entities must pay a fee to the Secretary for the reduction procedure. Any erroneous payments made to State entities will be addressed by the Secretary. The regulations specify State judicial debts eligible for reduction, with State entities paying a fee to the Secretary for the procedure. Any erroneous payments made to State entities must be promptly repaid to the Secretary. Amendments are made to sections of the Internal Revenue Code regarding disclosure of return information and conforming amendments. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including adding subsection (g) to certain paragraphs and redesignating section 6402(h) to include subsection (g) for reducing State judicial debts and crediting future tax liabilities. The amendments made by this Act include adding subsection (g) to certain paragraphs and redesignating section 6402(j) to include subsection (g) for reducing State judicial debts and crediting future tax liabilities. The effective date for these amendments is for refunds payable for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009.
